comment.body:
For storage, depending what OS you're on, compressing the zeronet data directories should help.  I would guess you thought of this already, though.  Was the compression not enough to help?

I've just started to learn the zeronet code, but from what I've seen so far, there is a lot of ram used for tracking.   To reduce ram, that could be moved to backing store (e.g., a database), but then the net might run slower.  Also, I'm not sure how efficient python is with certain things.  It may be a lower-level language like C++ could make more efficient use of RAM.

I've still been thinking about this issue.  Would getting a RaspberryPi and configuring it as a Zeronet proxy fix it?  It's spending a few bucks, but having a dedicated device to offload zeronet from you laptop may make sense and would be cheaper than a newer laptop.
Glad to see you're back.  Even though we've never spoken, I've been learning a lot from your many posts.  Hope things are going better for you now.

@Kaffie: Me too!  I read your last post on the memory and storage usage.  Can you post what's using most of the storage, etc.?  I like to work on behind-the-scenes / platform code, so I'm interested in helping to address these problems if possible.  Thanks!
